Author: Camry 2104
Review:
This ancient temple was built in the 11th year of Emperor Suiko (603), and is said to be one of the Seven Great Temples built by Prince Shotoku. The statue of Miroku Bodhisattva, which is the first National Treasure, is very famous. Even if you try to know more about it, you will be wrapped in a vague feeling. I don't think it makes sense to stick to the history of this Buddha. I don't think there is any other statue of Buddha with such dignity, and the fact that it has been so deeply revered by so many people for 1,400 years is enough.
Speaking of Koryu-ji Temple, it may be said that the Niomon Gate, which can be seen from Randen, is the most familiar. The front of the gate that feels like a commoner, the precincts that make you feel the Asuka period, and the Prince's faith. Although it is small, it is a temple with endless charm.

Author: Ë•øÂ≥∂‰∏âÈÉé
Review: Forty years ago, the principal image of Maitreya Bodhisattva, which became the first National Treasure, was always included in elementary school social studies textbooks. Unlike ordinary Buddha statues, it has a firm and toned body, giving the illusion that it is about to start moving and talk to you. Kobo Daishi Kukai seems to be one of the fascinated! Wooden statues of Prince Shotoku aged 2 and 16 are also enshrined, and there is a deep connection with related temples throughout the country, such as Tachibana-dera Temple in Asuka Village, Nara, where he was born. Please also see the wooden statues of Mr. and Mrs. Masaru Hatakawa, who were the most influential people in talking about Heiankyo! Matsuo-taisha, Kamigamo-jinja, Shimogamo-jinja, Kijima-jinja with the crest of Futaba Aoi, and Fushimi Inari-taisha, the head shrine of Inari, were probably founded by Mr. Hata who was a visitor! There are many traces of the Japan-U.S. same-ancestor theory. In the back of the narrow alley on the unpaved road next to the entrance to the wide free parking lot, there is a well called "Israel's Well üáÆüá±" by the locals, so why not stop by and see?

Author: Jituei Kobashi
Review:
It was a visit that made me understand why this temple is rarely featured in various tourist information and media.
Nandaimon, which faces the road where Randen runs, feels very close to people, and I thought it was very good. When I passed through the south gate and saw the spacious precincts of the temple, I felt as if I had come to an old temple in Nara.
Unfortunately, the connections between the cathedrals were bad, so I couldn't go inside, and the explanation wasn't enough, so I gradually lost the desire to go to the next cathedral.
I paid the admission fee for the first time when I entered the Reihoden, where Maitreya Bodhisattva is enshrined. I was rudely told to take off my woolen hat, which is a must-have for a person with no hair on my head.
It's also a place of prayer, but if you charge an admission fee, you need to consider (heating) the visitors!
From the people in charge in the hall, I felt the movements and gazes as if they were watching the visitors! I'm sorry, but I felt bad.
I felt that I should study more about how to deal with visitors, including the ticket office.
I understand why it is rarely featured in the media even though it is one of the oldest temples in Japan.

Author: Po-Wei Tseng
Review:
"Taiqin Guanglong Temple"
(2019.03.29)

The individual has many purposes in this trip,
One of them is to come to Taiqin and National Treasure No. 1
"Maitreya Bodhisattva half-heeled thinking image" to meet.

It's as if the Bodhisattva was saying, "It's time",
A beautiful picture is posted in front of the Guanglong Temple
The Maitreya Bodhisattva photo greeted us with a smiling face.

When I was happy, I didn't expect to turn up the stairs but I saw
Two wide-eyed vajra warriors stared at me,
As if saying: "Boy, I've been waiting for you for a long time!"
Let me restrain my excitement a little and enter the temple :P

The cherry blossoms in the temple were in bloom on this day, but there were not many tourists.
We bought tickets for worship and entered the Lingbao Hall.
Since I can't take pictures here, I can only say:

After entering the treasure hall, the first thing you will see on the left is the magnificent
"Twelve Generals", Sunlight, Moonlight Bodhisattva
And the unopened secret Buddha Yakushi Tathagata.
This part alone has left me dumbfounded.
As I admired it, I thought to myself:
"No wonder Japan is so strong in modeling technology" XD

After reading the Twelve Gods, I turned my attention to National Treasure No. 1.
I meditated here for a while, like thinking,
Then the Bodhisattva told me an important thing here:

"Hey, nothing is impossible,
Our troubles are as small as the sand of the Ganges,
Leave it to Him to think and lay down the burden here. "

*Then I left Guanglong Temple with a smile. ^^

Author: Â••ÊùëÊÖé‰πüÔºàOK computerÔºâ
Review:
Koryu-ji Temple is located in Uzumasa, which is famous for Toei Kyoto Studio Park, but it is unknown whether it was originally located in this area. It is widely believed that the temple was moved to its present location before or after the relocation of the capital. At the time of its foundation, the principal image of worship was Miroku Bosatsu, but around the time the capital was moved to Heian, it became a temple with Yakushi Nyorai as its principal image, and became a temple centered on the belief in Yakushi and Prince Shotoku. The principal image of Jogu Oin, which is the main hall of Koryu-ji Temple today, is a statue of Prince Shotoku. "Jogu Shotoku Hoo Teisetsu" lists Hachioka-ji Temple (Koryu-ji Temple) as one of the 'Seven Great Temples Built by the Prince'.
There are descriptions about the founding of Koryu-ji Temple in "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), etc., and it is certain that it was the temple of the Hata clan, but since the old records were lost due to the fire in 818, the early history of the temple is lost. is not always clear.
The Hata clan is said to be a naturalized Han Chinese who came from Qin (China) and came to Japan via the Korean Peninsula. Based in Kadono-gun (currently around the southern part of Ukyo Ward and Nishikyo Ward, Kyoto City), the family possessed techniques such as sericulture, weaving, sake brewing, and flood control. Kijimaza Amaterasu Mitama-jinja Shrine (silkworm shrine) near Koryu-ji Temple, Umenomiya Taisha Shrine in Umetsu, Ukyo Ward, and Matsuo Taisha Shrine in Arashiyama, Nishikyo Ward (both gods of sake brewing) are said to be shrines related to the Hata clan. Although there is Osake-jinja Shrine near Koryu-ji Temple, it was relocated from the precincts of Koryu-ji Temple to its current location due to the policy of separating Shintoism and Buddhism.

Author: Î∂ÄÏÇ∞ÏïÑÎπ† Busan Daddy ÈáúÂ±±Áà∏Áà∏
Review:
Wooden Bangasayusang, Japan National Treasure No. 1. Of course, like Korea's national treasure, Japan's national treasure number is not determined by evaluating the value of the relic, but the meaning of No. 1 is unique. If it was also strongly influenced by Baekje, or it may (almost certainly) be produced in Baekje, then Japan's National Treasure No. 1 has a strong color from the Korean Peninsula. Self-esteem rises.
Unfortunately, the wooden Bangasayu statue was exhibited in a small museum like other cultural festivals, but the lighting in the exhibition room was too dark. This seems to be a characteristic of Japan, but almost all temples and places where Buddha is enshrined are all dark. Except for places like museums.
It's so dark that I can't really appreciate it. You can't even feel the grain of the wood or the traces of the years. It was disappointing as I had high expectations.

Author: ‰∏ÉÈù¢È≥•ÊîæÊµ™Ë®ò
Review:
Todai-ji, Kofuku-ji, Horyu-ji, and a few other temples in Kyoto are the only temples in Kyoto that are comparable in terms of the quality of their Buddhist statues. Therefore, the evaluation is a comfortable five stars, but even though it is such a famous temple, it is plain. The worshipers are sparse and the parking lot is empty. The surrounding area is more of a residential area than a tourist spot, and there are far more people passing through the gate than passing through it, which makes me worry unnecessarily whether the management of the temple is okay. However, even if it is a residential area, access is convenient. Uzumasa Koryu-ji Station on the Arashiyama Electric Railway is just a stone's throw away from Romon Gate, and JR Uzumasa Station is within easy walking distance. Bus timetables are unreliable during the tourist season, so being close to the station is convenient. If you've been sightseeing around Arashiyama and still have time to catch the Shinkansen on your way home, don't hesitate to visit.
The Maitreya Bodhisattva statue, which is considered to be the first National Treasure, is a feast for the eyes just by looking at it, but we recommend that you fully enjoy it as much as time permits. There is also a bench in front of the statue, so it's okay if you're tired.

It is an ancient temple that I would strongly recommend as the end of your sightseeing in Kyoto.

I'm sure you've seen it somewhere, that Bodhisattva with a cane on his cheek.
In addition, Amida Nyorai and Senju Kanzeon Bodhisattva are displayed in Reihoden. Every Buddha statue is very impressive.
It is rare to find a temple where you can see so many national treasure Buddha statues at once.
For those who are interested in Buddhist statues, this temple is a must-see.

Author: Áî∞‰∏≠ÂÜ¨‰∏ÄÈÉéÔºà„Çπ„ÉäÔºâ
Review:
One of the Seven Great Temples of Japan built by Prince Shotoku. According to one theory, in the 11th year of Emperor Suiko (603) Kawakatsu Hata was built near Kita Ward, Kyoto City, with a Buddha statue given by Prince Shotoku as the principal image of worship.[Kyoto's oldest temple] ] (It is speculated that it was moved to its present location around the time of the transfer of the capital to Heian-kyo (794).)

In addition, although there is a fee, it is the first National Treasure designation at "Shin Reihokan", German existentialist philosopher Karl Jaspers said, "The highest ideal of human existence that has been truly perfected, the eternal peace of our hearts. The statue of Miroku Bodhisattva (Miroku), which has been highly acclaimed as "the most beautiful smile in the world on par with Mona Lisa's smile" (1960). The index finger of the right hand has also been safely restored), and the beautiful and well-balanced proportions of the large Buddha statues facing each other, "Standing Senju Kannon", "Fuku Kensaku Kannon", and "Seated Senju Kannon". A 16-year-old statue of Prince Shotoku, a statue of Twelve Divine Generals, and many other national treasure-class Buddhist statues made in the Kamakura period can be viewed up close and in a sacred and quiet atmosphere that is "because of the twilight." It is also known as a temple to visit.

In October, along with the Kurama Fire Festival and the Imamiya Shrine Yasurai Festival, it is one of the three major festivals of Kyoto. followed by holding a torch, and the [Beef Festival] was held around the precincts and surroundings. Unfortunately, it seems to have been discontinued since 2003.

Author: kaori miyazawa
Review:
When I started researching Sarutahiko, the god of guidance, I came across the visitor Mr. Hata. In order to learn about various things, it became necessary to first walk around the Uzumasa Koryu-ji Temple area. Take the Arashiyama Electric Railway from Uzumasa Tenjingawa Station to Koryu-ji Temple. When you get off, the mountain gate is right in front of you. From this point, head west towards Isarai, and walk along the temple wall to the right along the temple gate. is a set of walks. It seems that these were separated from the precincts by Haibutsu Kishaku.
It is said that there is a statue of Prince Shotoku in the shrine in Taishiden, wearing the costume that successive emperors wore after their accession to the throne. Unfortunately, I came three days after the doors opened on November 22nd. But why? ¬∑¬∑¬∑It's mysterious.
In Reihoden, there is a statue of a half-legged pensive that everyone knows. Located in the middle of a wide room, looking up. Unfortunately, the light is poor, and it's too far away, so I can't quite make out its expression. Therefore, I didn't feel much.
It took me half an hour to get my eyes adjusted to the darkness, and I watched it over and over again, but it just didn't work for me.
What caught my eye was the statue of Prince Shotoku sitting on a chair, which was good, and the Kawakatsu Hata and his wife, who were unskillful. 2 body. It's reminiscent of a seated figure, but it has no arms/legs... instead, a mirror is in front to hide its existence. Am I the only one who finds this unnatural?
I was glued to the statue of Kawakatsu. It's the first time I've seen a statue with such sharp eyes that widen my eyes...the eyes are stronger than the statue of Fudo Myoo.
It was the best to meet this statue here.
A temple full of ???
There were cherry blossoms in spring and autumn leaves in autumn, but I think Angle needs an explanation.

Author: Á•ûÊà∏Êò¥
Review: In front of Randen Uzumasa Koryuji Station. Built by Prince Shotoku during the reign of Emperor Suiko, it is one of the Seven Great Temples of Japan and is also called "Uzumasa no Taishi-do." It is also known as the clan temple of the Hata clan, who had power in this area. Unfortunately, as of December 2009, the Important Cultural Property Lecture Hall and National Treasure Katsuragi-in Temple are under renovation, but the museum has 20 national treasures from before the Nara period, 48 important cultural designated buildings, Buddhist statues, and works of art. increase. Although photography is prohibited, Buddhist statues can be viewed at the Shinreihoden Hall, and there are a number of national treasures and important cultural properties, such as the Miroku Bodhisattva statue, which was designated as Japan's No. 1 National Treasure. You can see the Buddha statue up close. In addition, the Prince Shotoku Gohitaki Festival, which is held on the anniversary of the death of Prince Shotoku on November 22nd, and the Uzumasa Beef Festival, which is currently suspended but is counted as one of the three major Kyoto festivals, are famous. You can get a goshuin at the visitor reception desk.

Author: Black diamond

Review:
The entrance fee is 800 yen, which is quite expensive compared to others, but perhaps because of the deterioration prevention, the inside of the museum was quite dark and I was not able to see it very well.
And the staff in the hall have a lot of orders. In the corona vortex, the bus that came here was full, probably because it was going to Arashiyama, so my body and mind were worn out. I wanted you to rest for a while. I could not worship the Buddha statue with a calm heart, and at first it was dark and I could not see it. My family, who had said they wanted to see it, later complained, "No matter how dark it is..." Be careful if you are near-sighted or bird-eyed. I can't see it in the dark.
If you go to Byodo-in Temple, the entrance fee including the museum is 600 yen for adults, which is cheaper than here. It was dimly lit, but the lighting was perfect, and I was able to see a number of wonderful exhibits. At least if you could do it with that kind of brightness.

Author: mksch00l
Review:
A temple built by the Hata clan who brought sericulture and weaving techniques to Japan. It has existed since before the transfer of the capital to Heian, and boasts a long history in Kyoto. I still have the place name
The seated statue of Maitreya Bodhisattva, which is the first designated national treasure, is so famous that you can freely visit the grounds except for the Treasure Hall, but the auditorium, which is the oldest structure in the grounds, was closed to the public due to the typhoon in September 2018. It is no longer possible (December 2018)

Revisited, I tried to enter the treasure hall (800 yen) for the first time in 20 years
In the past, probably because there were many students on school excursions, the sound of the tape was played periodically.
The statue of Miroku Bodhisattva is still beautiful, and I think there is an incident where a Kyoto University student fell in love with it and accidentally touched it, breaking the bodhisattva's finger.
The statue is made of Japanese red pine from the Korean Peninsula, and it is unknown whether it was an imported Buddha or carved in Japan, but Koreans are proud that Japan's first national treasure was made on the Korean Peninsula. And
The auditorium is currently undergoing restoration work, perhaps due to the effects of a typhoon, while the seated statue of Amida Nyorai (a national treasure) remains in the hall, and is expected to be completed in a few years.
As far as I know, this Amida Nyorai is the only National Treasure Buddha that can be viewed freely in Kyoto.

Author: suiko
Review:
The oldest temple in Yamashiro Province. It is located right next to Randen Uzumasa Koryuji Station.
It is a temple of the Shingon sect, and the principal object of worship is Prince Shotoku. Viewing is possible from 9:00.
It costs 800 yen to see the Reihoden, but there are many national treasures, including the statue of Miroku Bodhisattva. Unfortunately, the inside of the hall was dim, and I could not see the Buddha's expression well. I guess it can't be helped to protect cultural assets, but the Buddha at Rokuharamitsuji was much easier to see.
Goshuin can be registered at the reception desk.

Author: „ÅΩ„Çì
Review:
It is the oldest temple in Kyoto and enshrines Miroku Bodhisattva, designated as the first National Treasure.
It takes less than 10 minutes on foot from Uzumasa Station.
As you walk along the road, you will suddenly see a splendid Romon gate and Nio statues.

Except for the "Shinreihoden," where national treasures are stored, visitors can freely visit the shrine for free, so it was the cherry blossom season, and people who seemed to be locals also came to see the garden in the precincts.

After purchasing an admission ticket for Shinreihoden, you will find many large and small national treasure Buddha statues lined up in the dark inside.
(‚Äª Gradually, your eyes will get used to it, but it's really dark, probably because of the protection of cultural properties, and the place where the explanation is placed is hidden behind a fence, so it's hard to see, and it's far and small, so it's not suitable for people with poor eyesight or the elderly. If you have glasses or a bit of binoculars, it might be easier to see...)

The statue of Maitreya Bodhisattva is enshrined in the center.
I've seen it in textbooks, but the real thing is different from the photo, and has a really mysterious aura.
There are tatami mats in front of you, so you can sit and enjoy the view. In addition, in front of the statue of Maitreya Bodhisattva, there is also an amulet that you can purchase yourself.

Author: Èï∑ÈáéÂãùÂπ∏

Author: HedgeHodge ‚ÄúHodgePodge‚Äù

Author: „ÅØ„Å£„Å°„Çá
Review:
When I visited on a weekday afternoon, there were about 5 customers in the Reihoden. Everyone faced the Buddha statue and appreciated it carefully. The lighting inside the Reihoden seemed to be quite dim, but after a while after entering the building, my eyes got used to it, and I felt that the Buddha statues were actually floating in the air.

Among the three large Buddha statues enshrined opposite the Maitreya Bodhisattva statue in Reihoden, after a while facing the seated statue of Thousand Armed Kannon in the middle, I felt a great warmth gradually pouring into me. rice field. There is an absolute generosity that will forgive no matter what happens, and I think that is motherhood itself. I had never cried when I saw a Buddha statue, but since there weren't many other customers, I had them face each other slowly while wiping away their tears. Some of my arms were lost along the way, but the whole feeling, including the missing arms, was gentle, beautiful, and had a big presence. bottom. Just remembering it brings warm tears to my eyes.

In addition, the statue of Fukukensaku Kannon to the left of the seated statue of Thousand-armed Kannon has not only the beauty of its supple body, but also its eyes are in the distant flow of time. I felt like I was looking into immeasurable distance.

I was overwhelmed by the magnificence of these two statues. It was an unforgettable and wonderful experience.

By the way, the state of the precincts was not nice. The trees were poorly maintained, with many dead branches at the tips of the cherry trees and dead leaves all over the pine trees. Some areas near the auditorium under renovation were grassy.
Also, it seems that there is no official website. Although Koryu-ji has many wonderful Buddhist statues that can be said to be national treasures, it is a pity that the awareness and ability to attract customers is much lower than that of Kiyomizu-dera and Kinkaku-ji. It's a waste. By all means, I would like you to make it exciting so that many people can see the wonderful Buddha statues.
